title: 110_hr5856
content: The Act is titled the "Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Facility Authorization and Lease Act of 2008." It authorizes major medical facility projects for fiscal year 2009. In fiscal year 2009, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to carry out major medical facility projects including seismic corrections in Palo Alto, California, a polytrauma healthcare center in San Antonio, Texas, and seismic corrections in San Juan, Puerto Rico, with specified funding amounts for each project. SEC. 3. Modification of authorization amounts for certain major medical facility construction projects previously authorized. Modification of Major Medical Facility Authorizations under the Veterans Benefits, Health Care, and Information Technology Act of 2006 includes increasing funding to $625,000,000 and $769,200,000 for certain projects. Additionally, corrections for patient privacy deficiencies at the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Gainesville, Florida are addressed. The Benefits, Health Care, and Information Technology Act of 2006 is amended to increase funding for various construction projects, including a new medical center facility in Las Vegas, Nevada, a new outpatient clinic in Lee County, Florida, and a new medical center facility in Orlando, Florida. In Florida, funding for construction projects is increased, including a consolidation of campuses in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. The amendment changes the funding amounts from $377,700,000 to $656,800,000 and from $189,205,000 to $295,600,000. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION OF FISCAL YEAR 2009 MAJOR MEDICAL FACILITY LEASES. In fiscal year 2009, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to carry out major medical facility leases at various locations, with specified amounts for each lease. This includes outpatient clinics in Brandon, Colorado Springs, Eugene, Green Bay, Greenville, Mansfield, Mayaguez, Mesa, and interim research space in Palo Alto. In fiscal year 2009, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to carry out major medical facility leases at various locations, including outpatient clinics and research space in different states with allocated funds. For example, interim research space in Palo Alto, California receives $8,636,000, an outpatient clinic in Savannah, Georgia receives $3,168,000, an outpatient clinic in Sun City, Arizona receives $2,295,000, and a primary care annex in Tampa, Florida receives $8,652,000. Authorization of construction of major medical facility in Okaloosa County, Florida. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to construct a new medical facility in Okaloosa County, Florida, with a budget not exceeding $54,475,000. The facility will be built according to option 2 of a 2007 report to Congress. Additionally, a plan for sharing inpatient and outpatient services must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The terms and conditions for sharing inpatient and outpatient services at the authorized medical facility are outlined. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2009 major medical facility projects and leases for the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Total amounts authorized for construction projects and leases are specified. Facilities administration is also addressed. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must provide a progress report on facilities administration within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, an annual report on outpatient clinics is required. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is mandated to submit an annual report on community-based outpatient clinics and other outpatient clinics to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs of the Senate and House of Representatives. The report must include a list of each clinic, their types, locations, sizes, and the number of health services provided. The annual report on community-based outpatient clinics and other outpatient clinics includes details such as clinic type, location, size, number of health professionals, workload, lease status, and operating costs. It also lists clinics opened in the previous fiscal year, proposed clinics for the current and subsequent fiscal years, activation costs, and required information for each clinic. The annual report on community-based outpatient clinics and other outpatient clinics includes details such as clinic type, location, size, number of health professionals, workload, lease status, and operating costs. It also lists clinics under review by the National Review Panel and possible future clinic locations identified in the Department's strategic planning process. Additionally, it prioritizes sites of care that the Secretary could establish without construction or leasing, including sites that could be expanded by hiring additional staff or allocating staff to Federal facilities. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit the first annual report under section 8119(a) of title 38, United States Code within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. Section 807(e) of the Veterans Benefits, Health Care, and Information Technology Act of 2006 is amended to replace "Medical Care" with "Medical Facilities". This amendment was passed by the House of Representatives on May 21, 2008.
